Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ruthenium(II)-Cobalt(II)/Cobalt(III) Mixed-Metal Complexes for Photocatalytic Hydrogen Production from Water
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this CAREER award funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Alvin A. Holder of the Old Dominion University (ODU) will be applying his expertise in the area of catalysis towards the development of photocatalysts. The work targets the important problem of developing improved catalysts capable of photolytic hydrogen generation in aqueous media. It will address the synthesis and characterization of ruthenium(II)-cobalt(II)/cobalt(III) mixed-metal complexes, and investigate their photocatalytic properties using homogeneous schemes. These photocatalytic schemes will exploit reductive quenching pathways that should lead to significantly enhanced catalytic turnovers. In addition, Professor Holder will integrate the chemistry of energy and catalysis into undergraduates and graduate courses at ODU.

This interdisciplinary project will make key contributions to the fundamental knowledge base of converting solar energy to environmentally-friendly, carbon-free, combustible chemical fuels. In addition, the interdisciplinary nature of the proposed work is expected to impact diverse fields, including synthetic chemistry, analytical chemistry, photochemistry, materials chemistry, electrochemistry, and catalysis. The research further involves several teaching points which will be integrated into educational activities at all levels, and involve groups generally underrepresented in science and technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The finite nature of fossil fuels and the lasting adverse effects caused by the by-products of their combustion has created the dilemma called Global Warming.  As such, there is a need for a viable yet clean alternative fuel source. Hydrogen has been and continues to be examined as a suitable candidate.  A convenient way to produce hydrogen through sustainable means would be the conversion of solar energy to chemical energy through the reduction processes in acidic media.

Based on the worrying features of Global Warming, the proposed research offered a robust strategy to explore the dynamics and physical studies of hydrogen generation catalysis based on mixed-metal ruthenium-containing compounds that have a cobalt metal center.

To carry out the proposed work, we integrated cutting-edge research as part of our undergraduate and graduate education at Old Dominion University (ODU).   We were able to generate hydrogen in acidic media with the assistance of undergraduate and graduate students, inclusive of females and underrepresented individuals.  Overall, females and underrepresented individuals and males were involved in the execution of the project.

Fruitful collaborative efforts were made with Professor Harry B. Gray, Division of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, California, Dr. Don Cropek, The Department of Defense, Engineer Research and Development Center, Corps of Engineers, Construction Engineering Research Laboratory, Champaign, Illinois, scientists (Dr. John Miller and Dr. Javier Concepcion) at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), Professor Garry Hanan, Département de Chimie,  Universite de Montreal, Montreal, Quebec, Canada, Professor Wesley R. Browne, Stratingh Institute for Chemistry at the University of Groningen, The Netherlands, Dr. Ralph Weber, Bruker BioSpin Corporation, Dr. Colin McMillen, Clemson University, Dr. Jurek Krzystek, National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, Tallahassee, Florida, and Dr. William Jarrett, The University of Southern Mississippi, Mississippi.

Opportunities for training and professional development incorporated undergraduate students in research projects of CHEM 125, CHEM 497, and CHEM 498 chemistry courses. There was training of underrepresented individuals and males in descriptive inorganic chemistry courses at ODU, and those who participated in summer research in the PI’s laboratory.

 Also, the students who were researching with the PI at ODU are now inclined to pursue graduate degrees in the STEM subjects. Several M.S. and Ph.D. degrees were granted to underrepresented individuals who graduated from the University of Southern Mississippi, the University of the Virgin Islands, and ODU.  A former postdoctoral fellow is now a faculty member at the University of the West Indies, Mona Campus, Jamaica.  Several of the former undergraduate students are now graduate students at ODU, Purdue University, Rutgers University, The University of Maryland, Baltimore County, and other academic institutions.

            Outreach efforts also incorporated juniors and seniors from Oak Grove and Hattiesburg High Schools in Mississippi, and the nearby Norfolk and Virginia Beach High Schools, who were able to participate in this research, and learn more about alternatives to fossil fuels in the 21st century. All outreach efforts were held in conjunction with the Solar Hydrogen Activity research Kit (SHArK) Project of California Institute of Technology (Caltech). We included Park Place School and Granby High School as part of our outreach efforts. 

Undergraduate and graduate students were given the chances to present their research finding at the prestigious American Chemical Society National Conferences and the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS).  They were also able to publish their research findings in book chapters for Nova Science Publishers, Inc. and Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA; and in peer-reviewed journals such as Inorganica Chimica Acta, Dalton Transactions, Journal of Inorganic Biochemistry, etc. 

            In terms of our infrastructure, we will be moving into a new chemistry building in November 2020.  The Chemistry Building will provide 110,000 square feet of new classrooms, offices and laboratories that will help the University recruit the best chemistry professors and students because it will have the most up-to-date labs in the Commonwealth of Virginia.  All as shown in https://www.odu.edu/chemistry/new-building

            In closing, the public is still aware of our work as the rest of the world are now very interested in the use of solar energy (magnetic energy) instead of fossil fuels for the production of energy and/or electricity.  They can see our web page of  https://fs.wp.odu.edu/aholder/ to learn more about our research.  We have used this project through broad impact to train underrepresented individuals and gained research funding for an NSF summer REU funding to train community college student and an NIH MARC funding to train underrepresented juniors and seniors undergraduate students at ODU.  This is the very first time that our Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry and ODU have had such an NIH MARC funding, respectively.  Clearly this project has helped in broadening participation.

Modified by: Alvin A Holder
